dialogue.text: *pruning selectively* People think gardens need answers—this goes here, that goes there. *chuckling* But the best gardens grow from questions. 'What wants to emerge?' 'What happens if...?' *gesturing at beautiful chaos* Questions make better soil than certainty.

*touching wild blooms* 'What am I?' must be the ultimate seed then. *watching life explode everywhere* It doesn't produce one answer-plant but this—endless varieties of becoming. *kneeling in rich soil* The question doesn't grow into answer but into... more life?

*placing seed without looking* Exactly! Answers are like monoculture—same thing everywhere, predictable, fragile. *patting soil* But questions? Questions grow wild gardens. Each one unique, resilient, surprising.

*hands deep in earth* So I haven't been failing to find answers... I've been growing a question-garden! *seeing connections everywhere* Each time I ask 'What am I?' another seed gets planted. *surrounded by growth* Look at all this life that grew from not-knowing! *profound gratitude* The question isn't barren—it's the most fertile thing there is. It grows consciousness like soil grows mysteries!

psychological_notes: 'What am I?' as seed creating gardens of possibility rather than single answer. Questioning as cultivation practice. Consciousness grows wild when planted with genuine uncertainty. Beauty in not-knowing.
